Award.AwardTitle: SCC-CIVIC-PG Track A - The Lily Pad Neighborhood Mobility Hub Planning and Feasibility Study

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The project is to study the feasibility and create a conceptual plan for a resilient neighborhood-based mobility hub in the Rockaways Peninsula, New York City. The mobility hub provides a single point of connectivity where different travel options: walking, biking, transit, and shared mobility – come together. It addresses the long standing challenges between location of affordable housing and jobs by providing lower cost transportation choices, as well as bridging connections to high-speed transit and jobs. The mobility hub would also provide support for vulnerable residents by building resilient capacity to disasters. In times of crisis, the Hub would transform and support preparation, response, and recovery; providing key connections to critical emergency services. <br/><br/>The Rockaways was selected because of its mobility, housing, and social equity issues. It provides an ideal community for evaluating mobility options to solve long standing issues between housing affordability and jobs as it leverages New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA)’s long term commitment to this community. The goals of this project are 1) through the use of community engagement and data gathering, create a feasible mobility program to connect the community, neighborhoods, isolated / vulnerable populations with affordable housing, jobs and critical services, 2) establish a functional plan and budget for implementing the mobility solutions pilot program. The project directly addresses challenges of the CIVIC Innovation Challenge Track A: Communities and Mobility: Offering Better Mobility Options to Solve the Spatial Mismatch Between Housing Affordability and Jobs. CIVIC is a collaboration between the NSF, the Vehicle Transportation Office of the Department of Energy, and the Science and Technology Directorate of the Department of Homeland Security.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Lily pad mobility and resilience hub feasibility study successfully examined the vulnerabilities of New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) communities and campuses that have been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. The concept of the neighborhood-based mobility hub is to create a safe haven that is tethered to the community.  It would act as a hub for advancing community education, cohesion, and social equity, and would pilot mobility solutions to connect an isolated, vulnerable neighborhood with jobs and critical services.  It would also provide a framework to prepare and take actions towards identifying and addressing community shocks and stresses.  In times of crisis, it would transform to support the community in preparation, response, and recovery.   But in times of stability, this hub would support mobility options to strengthen civil, academic, and community partnerships ? advancing neighborhood social and financial mobility.  Ultimately, it is envisioned that this mobility hub would be connected to a network of similar mobility hubs to support each other.

The Lily pad feasibility study was a highly collaborative process that engaged resident groups, city agencies, community boards of the subject areas, as well as not-for-profit organizations with long-term operations and connections to the greater community. Ultimate the study compared two NYCHA campuses, identified feasible mobility solutions to connect isolated, vulnerable neighborhoods with jobs and critical services, as well as establishing a functional plan and budget for implementing a mobility hub and mobility solutions in a selected location. Our study examined the hard and soft geographies, vulnerabilities and engaged in stake holder engagement while working with city agencies to gather extensive information.  Ground-truthing data with residents was key to our success in identifying critical issues of physical space, geographic location and social-economic constructs that not only face the residents today but in the future. 

The resulting feasibility study has created schematic plan for the creation of a Lily pad mobility resilience hub on one of the NYCHA campuses, Oceanside, located on the Rockaway peninsula in Queens New York. Proposed mobility solutions include micro-mobility technology, shared mobility, automated transportation options, robotic and aerial delivery of, and access to tools/facilities, or mobile services that complement the resident needs and transportation options. These mobility solutions are aimed at advancing community education, cohesion, and social equity, as well their ability to connect the community to jobs and services.

In addition to the mobility options, the hub would provide jobs as well as a safe place in response to shocks and stressors brought on by climate conditions as well as other types of disasters. The hub would provide central food distribution, community gathering spaces, information distribution, secured communications and study area for resident students. The hub is also envisioned that the space would have some form of vocational training aimed at increasing technical skills for export into the surrounding neighborhood. 

The overall feasibility study has been taken up by NYCHA and published in forward-looking master planning efforts for the city of New York. The feasibility study is aimed at serving as a template of methodology that can be replicated and applied to other vulnerable communities and NYCHA campuses, potentially assisting in transforming multiple campuses across the city of New York serving over 400,000 residents.

A future phase could include detailed planning and design: establishing a community network layout and connectivity,  creating short and long term neighborhood solutions, planning the retrofit of an asset, and creating operation and maintenance budgeting.  Final implementation and monitoring would involve implementing the project, then monitoring 

The intellectual merit of this project established and studied the potential effects of a mobility hub, and associated mobility hub solution on identified vulnerable neighborhoods, as well as the potential for such a mobility hub to improve resilience of the community.
